[[File:Brahmi Kya (Ka-Ya) conjunct consonant.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|"Kya" (Ka+Ya) conjunct consonant in the [[Brahmi script]], consisting in the vertical assembly of consonants "Ka" [[File:Brahmi k.svg|12px]] and "Ya" [[File:Brahmi y.svg|12px]]. Used in the spelling of the word "[[Shakyas|Shakyamuni]]" to designate the [[Buddha]], [[Lumbini|Rummindei pillar]] of [[Ashoka]] (circa 250 BCE).]] '''Conjunct consonants''' are a type of letters, used for example in [[Brahmi script|Brahmi]] or modern [[Devanagari]], to write [[consonant cluster]]s such as {{IPA|/pr/}} or {{IPA|/rv/}}. Although most of the time, letters are formed by using a simple consonant with the inherent value vowel "a" (as with "k" [[File:Brahmi k.svg|12px]], pronounced "ka" in Brahmi), or by combining a consonant with an vowel in the form of an [[diacritic]] (as with "ki" [[File:Brahmi letter Ki.svg|12px]] in Brahmi), the usage of conjunct consonant permits the creation of more sophisticated sounds (as with "kya" [[File:Brahmi Kya.jpg|12px]], formed with the consonants k [[File:Brahmi k.svg|10px]] and y [[File:Brahmi y.svg|10px]] assembled verticaly).<ref name=MC/> Conjuncts are often used with loan words. Native words typically use the basic consonant and native speakers know to suppress the vowel.
In modern Devanagari the components of a conjunct are written left to right when possible (when the first consonant has a vertical stem that can be removed at the right), whereas in Brahmi characters are joined vertically downwards.<ref name=MC>{{cite book |last1=Shapiro |first1=Michael C. |title=A Primer of Modern Standard Hindi |date=1989 |publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ. |isbn=9788120805088 |page=23 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vvuP8sD1wloC&pg=PA23 |language=en}}</ref>
Some simple examples of conjunct consonants in Devanagari are: त + व = त्व tva, ण + ढ = ण्ढ ṇḍha, स + थ = स्थ stha, where the vertical stroke of the first letter is simply lost in the combination. Sometimes, conjunct consonants are not clearly derived from the letters making up their components: the conjunct for kṣ is क्ष (क् + ष) and for jñ it is ज्ञ (ज् + ञ).
Conjunct consonants are used in many other scripts as well, usually derived from the Brahmi script.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Tuṅga |first1=Sudhāṃśu Śekhara |title=Bengali and Other Related Dialects of South Assam |date=1995 |publisher=Mittal Publications |isbn=9788170995883 |page=163 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lRRYBHQvXdsC&pg=PA163 |language=en}}</ref> In [[Balinese script|Balinese]], conjunct consonants are called ''Haksara Wrehastra''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shadeg |first1=Norbert |title=Tuttle Balinese-English Dictionary |date=2014 |publisher=Tuttle Publishing |isbn=9781462910786 |page=11 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=20ktBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 |language=en}}</ref>
Conjunct consonant are not limited to Brahmic languages, and can be seen in [[Navajo language|Navajo]] for example.<ref>{{cite book |last1=McDonough |first1=J. M. |title=The Navajo Sound System |date=2003 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=9781402013522 |page=29 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T6VUuphai7wC&pg=PA29 |language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{redirect|Iconic|other uses|Icon (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Motherhood and apple pie.jpg|thumb|300px||right|Apple pie, baseball, and the United States flag are three American cultural icons]]
A '''cultural icon''' is an [[cultural artifact|artifact]] that is identified by members of a culture as representative of that culture. The process of identification is subjective, and "icons" are judged by the extent to which they can be seen as an authentic proxy of that culture. When individuals perceive a cultural icon, they relate it to their general perceptions of the cultural identity represented.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grayson|first=Kent|last2=Martinec|first2=Radan|date=2004-09-01|title=Consumer Perceptions of Iconicity and Indexicality and Their Influence on Assessments of Authentic Market Offerings|url=https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/31/2/296/1824949/Consumer-Perceptions-of-Iconicity-and-Indexicality|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|volume=31|issue=2|pages=296–312|doi=10.1086/422109|issn=0093-5301}}</ref> Cultural icons can also be identified as an authentic representation of the practices of one culture by another.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Motley|first=Carol M.|last2=Henderson|first2=Geraldine Rosa|date=2008-03-01|title=The global hip-hop Diaspora: Understanding the culture|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0148296307001609|journal=Journal of Business Research|series=Cross-Cultural Business Research|volume=61|issue=3|pages=243–253|doi=10.1016/j.jbusres.2007.06.020}}</ref>
In the [[mass media|media]], many items and persons of [[popular culture]] have been called "iconic" despite their lack of durability; and the term "[[pop icon]]" is often now used. Some commentators believe that the word is overused or misused.<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-3713610.html Heard about the famous icon? We have - far too often], ''The Independent'' (London), January 27, 2007</ref>
==Examples== [[File:Red telephone box, St Paul's Cathedral, London, England, GB, IMG 5182 edit.jpg|thumb|upright|A [[red telephone box]] is a [[List of cultural icons of the United Kingdom|British cultural icon]]]] A web-based survey was set up in 2006 allowing the public to nominate their ideas for [[national icons]] of England<ref name=England>{{cite web|url=http://www.icons.org.uk/theicons/index.html|title=Our Collection|publisher=icons.org.uk|accessdate=August 16, 2014}}</ref> and the results reflect the range of different types of icon associated with an English view of English culture. Some examples are:
* [[Big Ben]] (the nickname for the bell, but widely recognised as Elizabeth Tower of the [[Houses of Parliament]] in London);<ref name=PostalMuseum/><ref name=Holloway>{{cite book | title=The Business of Tourism | publisher=Pearson Education |author1=Holloway, J Christopher |author2=Taylor, Neil | edition=7th ed., 2006 (First published 1983) | pages=217}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=An Unstoppable Force: Daring to Become the Church God Had in Mind | publisher=Flagship Church Resources | author=McManus, Erwin Raphael | year=2001 | pages=113}}</ref> * [[Cup of tea]] (for the [[Tea in the United Kingdom|British tea]] drinking habit);<ref name=PostalMuseum/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/3790147.stm BBC: Tea steams ahead in icon hunt]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=The 100 Words that Make the English | publisher=Hachette Digital (e-book) | author=Thorne, Tony | work=Cuppa | year=2011}}</ref> * [[Red telephone box]];<ref name=PolicyExchange/><ref name=Culture24/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://gulfnews.com/about-gulf-news/al-nisr-portfolio/weekend-review/articles/to-save-a-past-that-rings-a-bell-1.40988 | title=Gulf News / Christian Science Monitor | work=To save a past that rings a bell | date=2 April 2009 | accessdate=December 15, 2012 | author=O'Neill, Brendan}}</ref> * Red [[AEC Routemaster]] London double decker bus;<ref name=PostalMuseum/><ref name=PolicyExchange>{{cite web | url=http://www.policyexchange.org.uk/images/publications/replacing%20the%20routemaster%20-%20oct%2005.pdf | title=Replacing the Routemaster | date=October 2005 | accessdate=December 15, 2012 | author=Jenkins, Simon; Dean Godson (editor) | pages=7}}</ref><ref name=Culture24/> * [[Spitfire]], a [[World War II]] fighter aircraft.<ref name=PostalMuseum>[http://postalheritage.org.uk/page/icons British Postal Museum & Archive: Icons of England]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref name=Culture24>[http://www.culture24.org.uk/art362437 Culture24: Icons of England]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=Cultural Icons: A Case Study Analysis of their Formation and Reception (PhD Thesis) | publisher=University of Central Lancashire | author=Parker, Mike | work=Chapter 5: The Spitfire Aircraft | year=2012 | pages=123–167}}</ref>
[[Matryoshka doll]]s are seen internationally as cultural icons of [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kodiakdailymirror.com/view/full_story/16723558/article-Scuttlebutt--Wooden-toy-tells-a-story-of-love-and-industry-? | title=Scuttlebutt: Wooden toy tells a story of love and industry | publisher=Kodiak Daily Mirror | date=25 December 2012 | accessdate=9 April 2013 | author=Bobo, Suzanna}}</ref> In the former [[Soviet Union]], the [[hammer and sickle]] symbol and statues of [[Vladimir Lenin]] instead represented the country's most prominent cultural icons.
The values, norms and ideals represented by a cultural icon vary both among people who subscribe to it, and more widely among other people who may interpret cultural icons as symbolising quite different values. Thus an [[apple pie]] is a cultural icon of the [[United States]], but its significance varies among Americans.
National icons can become targets for those opposing or criticising a regime, for example, crowds destroying statues of Lenin in Eastern Europe after the fall of communism<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2013/dec/09/smashing-statues-sweetest-revenge-protesters-lenin-kiev|publisher=Guardian|date=December 9, 2013|first=Jonathan|last=Jones|title=Why smashing statues can be the sweetest revenge}}</ref> or burning the [[American flag]] to protest US actions abroad.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/14/us-film-protests-idUSBRE88D0O320120914|publisher=Reuters|date=September 14, 2012|first=ulf|last=Laessing|title=Anti-American fury sweeps Middle East over film}}</ref>
[[Religious icon]]s can also become cultural icons in societies where religion and culture are deeply entwined, such as representations of the [[Madonna_(art)|Madonna]] in societies with a strong Catholic tradition.<ref>{{cite book|title=Creating Ourselves, African Americans and Hispanic Americans on popular culture and religious expression|editors=Anthony B Pinn and Benjamin Valentin|publisher=Duke University Press|date=2009}}</ref>
==Criticism== Describing something as ''iconic'' or as an ''icon'' has become very common in the popular media. This has drawn criticism from some: a writer in ''[[Liverpool Daily Post]]'' calls "iconic" "a word that makes my flesh creep", a word "pressed into service to describe almost anything."<ref name="LDP">[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-191891103.html Let's hear it for the Queen's English], ''[[Liverpool Daily Post]]''</ref> The ''[[Christian Examiner]]'' nominates "iconic" in its list of overused words, finding over 18,000 "iconic" references in news stories alone, with another 30,000 for "icon", including its use for ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]''.<ref name="CE">[http://www.christianexaminer.com/Articles/Articles%20Aug09/Art_Aug09_oped2.html Modern word usage amazingly leaves us yearning for gay, old times] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225101358/http://www.christianexaminer.com/Articles/Articles%20Aug09/Art_Aug09_oped2.html |date=2010-12-25 }}, ''[[Christian Examiner]]''</ref>
==See also== *[[:Category:Lists of cultural icons]] * [[List of cultural icons of England]] * [[List of cultural icons of France]] * [[List of cultural icons of Germany]] * [[List of cultural icons of Italy]] * [[List of cultural icons of the Netherlands]] * [[List of cultural icons of Northern Ireland]] * [[List of cultural icons of Russia]] * [[List of cultural icons of Scotland]] * [[List of cultural icons of Spain]] * [[List of cultural icons of Wales]] *[[Popular culture]] *[[Horror icon]]
== References == {{reflist|33em}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book | author=Biedermann, Hans | title=Dictionary of Symbolism: Cultural Icons and the Meanings Behind Them | publisher=Meridan| year=1994}} * {{cite book | author=Brooker, Will | title=Batman Unmasked: Analysing a Cultural Icon | publisher=Continuum | year=2001}} * {{cite book | author=Edwards, Peter; Karl Enenkel, and Elspeth Graham (editors) | title=The Horse as Cultural Icon: The Real and the Symbolic Horse in the Early Modern World | publisher=Brill| year=2011}} * {{cite book |author1=Foudy, Julie |author2=Leslie Heywood |author3=Shari L Dworkin | title=Built to Win: The Female Athlete as Cultural Icon | publisher=University of Minnesota Press| year=2003}} * {{cite book | author=Gilbert, Erik | title=The Dhow as Cultural Icon | publisher=Boston University| year=2008}}* {{cite book | author=Heyer, Paul | title=Titanic Century: Media, Myth, and the Making of a Cultural Icon | publisher=Praeger| year=2012}} * {{cite book | author=Heyer, Paul | title=Titanic Century: Media, Myth, and the Making of a Cultural Icon | publisher=Praeger| year=2012}} * {{cite book | author=Meyer, Denis C. | title=Cles Pour la France en 80 Icones Culturelles | publisher=Hachette| year=2010}} * {{cite book |author1=Nelkin, Dorothy |author2=M Susan Lindee | title=The DNA Mystique: The Gene as a Cultural Icon | publisher=University of Michigan Press| year=2004}} * {{cite book | author=Reydams-Schils, Gretchen J | title=Plato's Timaeus as Cultural Icon | publisher=University of Notre Dame Press| year=2003}}
==External links== * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/photography/6210040/Our-new-icons---by-photographer-Alison-Jackson.html Our New Icons] by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' * [http://www.theage.com.au/opinion/society-and-culture/nothing-and-no-one-are-off-limits-in-an-age-of-iconomania-20090914-fntq.html Nothing and no one are Off Limits in an Age of Iconomania] by ''[[The Age]]'' * [http://postalheritage.org.uk/page/icons British Postal Museum & Archive: Icons of England] * [http://www.culture24.org.uk/art362437 Culture24: Icons of England]
